bug.author: ytyfeng
bug.description:
ImportError: /lib64/libm.so.6: version 'GLIBC_2.27' not found When I tried to install Open3D from source on a ppc64le system, I was able to compile and install it using make, but I wasn't able to import it and use it in Python because of a GLIBC issue. It seems that Open3D works for GLIBC versions up to 2.27 but not 2.28, since the GLIBC version is 2.28 on my system. To Reproduce Steps to reproduce the behavior:
git clone --recursive https://github.com/intel-isl/Open3D cd Open3D; mkdir build; cd build cmake -DPYTHON_EXECUTABLE=`which python` -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=~/ .. make -j$(nproc) make install-pip-package python -c "import open3d"
Expected behavior When I import Open3D in Python, it gives me this error: <denchmark-code>$ python -c "import open3d" Traceback (most recent call last): File "<string>", line 1, in <module> File "/home/.conda/envs/test/lib/python3.6/site-packages/open3d/__init__.py", line 35, in <module> from .open3d import * # py2 py3 compatible ImportError: /lib64/libm.so.6: version `GLIBC_2.27' not found (required by /home/.conda/envs/test/lib/python3.6/site-packages/open3d/open3d.cpython-36m-powerpc64le-linux-gnu.so) </denchmark-code>
Environment:
OS: CentOS 7, ppc64le architecture Python version: 3.6 Open3D version: latest Is this remote workstation?: yes How did you install Open3D?: build_from_source
<denchmark-code>$ ldd --version ldd (GNU libc) 2.28 Copyright (C) 2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
$ gcc --version gcc (GCC) 8.3.1 20190304 (Advance-Toolchain-at12.0) [revision 269374] Copyright (C) 2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.
</denchmark-code>
Additional context Additionally, is it possible to provide a conda package that can be used on ppc64le systems? Currently when I try to use conda to install Open3D, it cannot find the package that would work for my system. When I use conda install -c open3d-admin open3d, it gives me this error: <denchmark-code>PackagesNotFoundError: The following packages are not available from current channels:
- open3d </denchmark-code>
